title: World Development Indicators (2022)
text:
Motivation

The World Development Indicators (WDI) provide a snapshot of economic and social conditions across countries.
This presentation summarizes patterns in GDP per capita, life expectancy, and unemployment for 2022.

title: World Development Indicators (2022)
text:
Data

One-year sample (2022) with 14 indicators
Unit of observation: country
Source: World Bank, World Development Indicators (WDI)

title: World Development Indicators (2022)
text:
Key Indicator 1: GDP per Capita

Takeaway: GDP per capita is strongly right-skewed, with a small number of very high-income countries.

title: World Development Indicators (2022)
text:
Life Expectancy

Takeaway: Life expectancy is more concentrated than GDP per capita.

title: World Development Indicators (2022)
text:
GDP and Life Expectancy

Takeaway: Higher GDP per capita is generally associated with higher life expectancy, with smaller gains at high income levels.

title: World Development Indicators (2022)
text:
Unemployment Rate

Takeaway: Unemployment varies widely across countries.

title: World Development Indicators (2022)
text:
Conclusion

GDP per capita shows large cross-country inequality.
Life expectancy is more evenly distributed and positively related to income.
Unemployment differs substantially across countries.

Next step: Extend this analysis across multiple years to study trends.

title: DATASCI Assignment 5
text:
Exploratory Data Analysiss (Q3)

In this section, I plan to look at three key development indicators for 2022: GDP per capita, life expectancy, and unemployment rate.

1. GDP per Capita
GDP per capita measures the average economic output per person and is often used as an indicator of a country’s standard of living.


   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's 
    259    2571    7588   20346   25983  240862      14 









We can see that the distribution is strongly right-skewed, indicating that most countries have relatively low to middle income levels, while a small number of countries have very high GDP per capita.



2. Life Expectancy
Life expectancy represents the average number of years a newborn is expected to live under current mortality conditions.


   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's 
  53.00   66.78   73.51   72.42   78.47   85.38       8 









Life expectancy appears more normally distributed compared to GDP per capita. Most countries cluster between 65 and 80 years, with fewer countries experiencing extremely low life expectancy.

3. Unemployment Rate
The unemployment rate measures the percentage of the labor force that is without work but actively seeking employment.


   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's 
  0.130   3.501   5.537   7.269   9.455  37.852      31 









Unemployment rates vary considerably across countries. While many countries report moderate unemployment levels, a subset experiences very high unemployment, suggesting structural labor market challenges.

title: DATASCI Assignment 5
section: Relationship Between Economic and Health Outcomes (Q4)
text:
Relationship Between Economic and Health Outcomes (Q4)








Figure 1: Relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy in 2022. Data source: World Bank WDI (sample in wdi.csv).





Figure Figure 1 shows that countries with higher GDP per capita tend to have higher life expectancy, with diminishing returns at the high-income end.








Figure 2: Top 10 countries by GDP per capita in 2022. Data source: World Bank WDI (sample in wdi.csv).





Figure Figure 2 presents the top 10 countries ranked by GDP per capita in 2022. The distribution highlights substantial disparities in income levels across countries. The highest-income countries significantly outperform others, indicating strong economic productivity and high standards of living. The large gaps between ranks suggest that global income distribution remains highly unequal. This positive association between income and life expectancy has been widely documented in the literature (Preston 1975).

title: DATASCI Assignment 5
text:
Highlighting key statistics & Conclusions (Q5)




Table 1: Key summary statistics for selected indicators (2022).




Key summary statistics for selected indicators (2022). Data source: World Bank WDI (sample in wdi.csv).










GDP per capita (mean)
GDP per capita (median)
Life expectancy (mean)
Life expectancy (median)
Unemployment rate (mean)
Unemployment rate (median)




20345.71
7587.59
72.42
73.51
7.27
5.54








Table Table 1 summarises key descriptive statistics for selected development indicators in 2022. The mean and median GDP per capita differ substantially, indicating a right-skewed distribution driven by a small number of high-income countries. In contrast, life expectancy shows less dispersion between the mean and median, suggesting a more concentrated global distribution. Unemployment rates display moderate variation, reflecting differences in labour market conditions across countries.

title: DATASCI Assignment 5
text:
Conclusion
This analysis of the 2022 World Development Indicators highlights substantial variation in economic and social outcomes across countries. GDP per capita exhibits strong inequality, with a small number of high-income countries significantly outperforming others. Life expectancy appears more evenly distributed, though it remains positively associated with economic prosperity. Unemployment rates vary across countries, reflecting structural and economic differences in labour markets.
Overall, the findings suggest that economic development remains closely linked to health outcomes, while disparities in income and employment conditions continue to shape global inequality patterns.
